definitions: praise someone insincerely and excessively to please or gain favor
make something appear more attractive or better than reality
examples: She tried to flatter her boss with excessive compliments
The salesman flattered the customer about her excellent taste
This lighting really flatters your features in photographs
The dress flatters her figure by emphasizing her best features

definitions: display something ostentatiously to provoke envy or admiration from others
examples: She loved to flaunt her expensive jewelry at parties
The celebrity flaunted his wealth on social media constantly

definitions: give a distinctive taste to food or drink by adding ingredients
examples: She flavored the soup with fresh herbs and garlic
The chef flavored the dessert with vanilla and cinnamon

definitions: give a distinctive taste to food or drink by adding ingredients
examples: She flavoured the soup with fresh herbs and garlic
The chef flavoured the dessert with vanilla and cinnamon

definitions: create or cause an imperfection or weakness in something
examples: The accident flawed the diamond beyond repair unfortunately
Poor planning flawed the entire project from the beginning

definitions: strip the skin off an animal or person by cutting
criticize someone severely and mercilessly in public or private
examples: The hunter carefully flayed the deer after the hunt
Medieval torturers would flay prisoners as a form of punishment
The critics flayed the director's latest film mercilessly
The boss flayed the team for missing the important deadline

definitions: mark or dot something with small patches of color or particles
examples: Paint flecked her clothes after the renovation project
Sunlight flecked the forest floor through the leaves above

definitions: grow feathers necessary for flight as a young bird
develop the skills and independence needed to leave parental care
examples: The baby eagles fledged after eight weeks in the nest
Most songbirds fledge within three weeks of hatching
The startup company has finally fledged into a successful business
Her children have all fledged and left home for college

definitions: run away quickly from danger or something unpleasant
examples: The villagers fled when the volcano began erupting violently
She fled the country to escape political persecution

definitions: remove the wool from a sheep by shearing or cutting
obtain money from someone by overcharging or swindling them dishonestly
examples: The farmers fleece their sheep twice every year
She learned to fleece sheep during her farm apprenticeship
The dishonest mechanic fleeced customers with unnecessary repairs
Tourist traps often fleece visitors with inflated prices

definitions: add more details or substance to make something more complete
examples: The writer needs to flesh out the characters more
Let's flesh out this proposal before presenting it tomorrow

definitions: bend a joint or contract muscles to show movement or strength
display one's power, wealth, or abilities to impress others deliberately
examples: The athlete flexed his biceps for the photograph
She flexed her fingers to relieve the stiffness
The company flexed its market power against smaller competitors
He loves to flex his wealth on social media platforms

definitions: strike or propel something with a quick sharp movement
move or cause to move with a sudden quick motion
examples: She flicked the light switch to illuminate the room
He flicked the crumb off the table with his finger
The horse flicked its tail to chase away flies
She flicked through the magazine while waiting patiently

definitions: shine with an unsteady or wavering light that varies in brightness
make small quick movements or appear briefly
examples: The candle flickered in the wind from the window
The old television screen flickered before going completely dark
A smile flickered across her face for just a moment
His eyes flickered nervously between the door and window

definitions: arrange or schedule an aircraft journey for passengers or cargo
examples: The airline flighted additional planes for the holiday season
They flighted the cargo shipment through Dubai yesterday

definitions: throw or hurl something forcefully with a sudden movement
engage in something with reckless abandon or enthusiasm
examples: She flung the door open in anger and stormed out
He flung his backpack onto the bed after school
They flung themselves into the new project enthusiastically
She flung caution to the wind and quit her job

definitions: turn something over quickly with a sudden sharp movement
suddenly become very angry or lose emotional control
examples: The chef expertly flipped pancakes in the busy kitchen
She flipped the page to continue reading the story
He completely flipped when he heard the terrible news
My parents will flip if they find out about this

definitions: behave playfully in a way that suggests romantic or sexual interest
show a casual or superficial interest in an idea or activity
examples: They flirted with each other at the office party
She loves to flirt but rarely dates anyone seriously
The company flirted with bankruptcy before recovering financially
He flirted with the idea of changing careers entirely

definitions: rest or move on the surface of a liquid without sinking
move slowly and lightly through air or space
suggest an idea tentatively to test reactions from others
examples: The boat floated gently on the calm lake water
Dead leaves floated on the surface of the pool
Clouds floated across the bright blue sky peacefully
The balloon floated away into the distance slowly
She floated the proposal at the morning meeting
Let me float this idea past you for feedback

definitions: move or gather together in large numbers as a crowd
examples: Tourists flock to the beach every summer vacation season
Birds flock together before migrating south for winter

definitions: cover or submerge an area with large amounts of water
arrive or occur in overwhelming amounts or large numbers
examples: Heavy rains flooded the basement during the storm
The river flooded several towns along its banks yesterday
Complaints flooded the company after the service outage
Memories flooded back when she visited her childhood home

definitions: knock someone to the ground with a physical blow
surprise or astonish someone so much they cannot respond
examples: The boxer floored his opponent with one powerful punch
The tackle floored the quarterback during the play
The unexpected news completely floored everyone in attendance
Her brilliant performance floored the judges and audience

definitions: fall, move, or hang in a heavy, loose, or ungainly way
fail totally, especially in an entertainment or business context
examples: He flopped onto the couch after the exhausting workout
The fish flopped around on the deck of the boat
The expensive movie flopped at the box office nationwide
His comedy routine flopped with the tough audience

definitions: struggle or stagger clumsily in water, mud, or when walking
struggle mentally to find direction or make progress
examples: The hikers floundered through the deep snow drifts
She floundered in the water before finding her footing
The student floundered when asked unexpected difficult questions
The company floundered without strong leadership guidance

definitions: sprinkle or coat something with flour for cooking preparation
examples: She carefully floured the pan before adding cake batter
The chef floured the fish before frying it golden

definitions: grow or develop in a healthy or vigorous way
wave something dramatically to attract attention
examples: The plants flourished in the greenhouse environment perfectly
Her business flourished after the new marketing campaign
He flourished his cape before beginning the magic trick
The conductor flourished her baton to start the symphony

definitions: move steadily and continuously in a current or stream
proceed or develop smoothly without interruption
examples: Water flows downhill toward the ocean naturally
Blood flows through our veins and arteries constantly
The conversation flowed naturally between old friends
Traffic finally began flowing after the accident cleared

definitions: produce flowers or be in bloom as a plant
examples: The roses flower beautifully in early summer months
Most fruit trees flower before producing their fruit

definitions: rise and fall irregularly in number, amount, or quality
examples: Stock prices fluctuate daily based on market conditions
Her mood fluctuates depending on her stress levels

definitions: shake or pat something to make it appear fuller and softer
fail to perform something properly, especially lines in acting
examples: She fluffed the pillows before the guests arrived
The hairdresser fluffed her hair for more volume
The actor fluffed his lines during the crucial scene
She fluffed the presentation by forgetting key points

definitions: move in an agitated, confused, or hurried manner
examples: She flurried around the kitchen preparing for dinner guests
The staff flurried about when the inspector arrived unexpectedly

definitions: clean something by causing large quantities of water to flow through
become red in the face from emotion, heat, or illness
force a person or animal to leave a hiding place
examples: Please flush the toilet after using the bathroom
They flushed the pipes to remove the blockage
She flushed with embarrassment when caught lying
His face flushed red from the intense heat
The dogs flushed the birds from the tall grass
Police flushed the suspect out of the building

definitions: speak, sing, or sound in a melodious, high-pitched manner
make grooves or furrows in a surface for decoration
examples: She fluted her words in a high melodious voice
The bird fluted its morning song from the treetop
The carpenter fluted the columns for the restoration project
The pastry chef fluted the edges of the pie crust

definitions: move with quick, light, flapping movements like bird wings
move or act in a nervous, restless, or excited manner
examples: Butterflies fluttered among the garden flowers all afternoon
The flag fluttered in the gentle breeze constantly
Her heart fluttered when he entered the room suddenly
She fluttered around the house before guests arrived

definitions: flow or discharge continuously in a state of constant change
examples: The situation continued to flux throughout the negotiations
Market conditions flux constantly in response to global events

definitions: move through air using wings or mechanical means
travel in an aircraft as pilot or passenger
move or pass very quickly through space or time
flee or escape from a place or situation rapidly
examples: Birds fly south for the winter every year
The kite flew high in the strong wind
She flies to London twice a month for business
The pilot flew the plane through terrible weather
Time flies when you're having fun with friends
The car flew past us on the highway
They had to fly the country during the revolution
The criminals flew before police could arrive

definitions: give birth to a foal as a female horse
examples: The mare foaled early this morning in the stable
She is expected to foal sometime next month

definitions: produce or form a mass of small bubbles or froth
examples: The waves foamed against the rocky shore violently
The beer foamed over the edge of the glass

definitions: deceive someone into accepting something inferior or unwanted
examples: Don't let them fob you off with excuses
He tried to fob inferior goods onto unsuspecting customers

definitions: become covered with condensed water vapor or mist
make something confused, unclear, or difficult to understand
examples: The bathroom mirror fogged up during the hot shower
The windows fogged in the cold winter morning
Don't try to fog the issue with irrelevant details
His mind was fogged by lack of sleep

definitions: prevent someone or something from being successful in plans or attempts
examples: Police foiled the bank robbery attempt yesterday afternoon
Bad weather foiled our plans for a picnic

definitions: bend something over on itself so one part covers another
mix ingredients gently by lifting and turning with a spoon
cease business operations due to financial failure
examples: She carefully folded the letter before placing it in envelope
He folded his arms across his chest defensively
Fold the egg whites into the cake batter gently
The chef folded chocolate chips into the cookie dough
The company folded after losing its major contracts
Several restaurants folded during the economic downturn

definitions: go or come after a person or thing moving ahead
come after something in time, order, or position
act according to instructions, rules, or advice given
understand the logic or meaning of something said or written
examples: The detective followed the suspect through the city
Please follow me to the conference room upstairs
Spring follows winter in the seasonal cycle naturally
The dessert course follows the main course traditionally
Students must follow all school rules and regulations
She follows a strict diet for health reasons
I couldn't follow his complicated explanation at all
Do you follow what I'm trying to say?

definitions: instigate or stir up unrest, violence, or trouble deliberately
examples: Extremists tried to foment rebellion against the government
The agitators fomented discord among the workers

definitions: trick or deceive someone into believing something false
behave in a playful, silly, or frivolous manner
examples: Don't let his friendly manner fool you completely
She fooled everyone with her clever disguise
Stop fooling around and get back to work
The children were fooling in the playground happily

definitions: pay the bill or cost for something, especially reluctantly
examples: The company will foot the bill for travel expenses
Parents often foot the bill for their children's education

definitions: add an explanatory or documenting note at the bottom of a page
examples: The author footnoted every historical claim in the book
Please footnote all your sources in the research paper

definitions: search widely for food or provisions, especially in nature
examples: Bears forage for berries in the forest during autumn
The soldiers had to forage for supplies behind enemy lines

definitions: make a sudden attack or raid into enemy territory
make an initial attempt or venture into a new area
examples: The troops forayed into enemy territory at dawn
Raiders forayed across the border during the night
The company forayed into the smartphone market last year
She forayed into politics after retiring from business

definitions: refuse to allow something or order someone not to do something
examples: The school forbids students from using phones during class
Her parents forbid her to date until she's sixteen
